instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.

threads.title: USBC Power (again) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Well, I thought I had the USB-C power negotiation sorted .. It seems not.

So I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no power.  

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>UPC_XB_GATE1</SIGNAL> = 0v
<SIGNAL>UPC_XB_GATE2</SIGNAL> = 4.9v

Now, why is the voltage at gate1 0 ?? How the hell does this USBC controller work

threads.title: USBC Power (again) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R3203</RESISTOR> - schematic says 15k/ NEED 0.1% - measures 12k
<RESISTOR>R3103</RESISTOR> - schematic says 15k/NEED 0.1% - measures 8k

Are these actually critical?? It seems unlikely

threads.title: USBC Power (again) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Why do you expect to get nominal value of a resistor measued onboard???

Check voltage and diode mode on ALL LDO outputs of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips; according to USB-C powered port.

threads.title: USBC Power (again) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: yes of course ... stupid error thinking that would be accurate.  So it looks like a short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and the USB-C controller might just be saving me from a fried CPU.  Pulled <RESISTOR>R7691</RESISTOR> and L7690 to isolate the voltage regulator.  Despite <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> looking like its had a blow torch on it the short is down circuit somewhere.  Let the hunt being

threads.title: USBC Power (again) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Quick update on this

The short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> on this board has ended up being a hard short (0.2ohm) at the CPU.  Louis posted back in 2018 that almost all <SIGNAL>P3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorts on the new platforms have been CPU shorts.  I swear it wasn't there when i started on this .. ahh well one for the parts bin
